title: "October 2024 Top 40 New CRAN Packages"
format: html

One hundred eighty-one new packages made CRAN's final cut in October. Here are my Top 40 picks in thirteen categories: AI, Climate Analysis, Computational Methods, Data, Epidemiology, Genomics, Machine Learning, Medicine, Quality Management, Statistics, Time Series, Utilities, and Visualization.

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="45%"}

### AI

[hollr](https://cran.r-project.org/package=hollr) v1.0.0: Enables chat completion and text annotation with local and [OpenAI](https://openai.com/) language models, and supports batch processing, multiple annotators, and consistent output formats. See [README](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/hollr/readme/README.html).

[spBPS](https://cran.r-project.org/package=spBPS) v0.0-4: Provides functions for Bayesian Predictive Stacking within the Bayesian transfer learning framework for geospatial artificial systems, as described in [Rewaiccw & Banerjee (2024)](https://arxiv.org/abs/2410.09504). Core functions leverage `C++` making the framework well-suited for large-scale spatial data analysis in parallel and distributed computing environments. 

![](spBPS.png){fig-alt="Heatmaps of Spacial Processes"}


[tidyllm](https://cran.r-project.org/package=tidyllm) v0.1.0: Implements a tidy interface for integrating large language model (LLM) APIs such as [Claude](https://www.anthropic.com/), [ChatGPT](https://openai.com/), [Groq](https://groq.com/), and local models via [Ollama](https://ollama.com/) into R workflows and supports text and media-based interactions, interactive message history, stateful rate limit handling, and a tidy, pipeline-oriented interface for streamlined integration into data workflows. See the [vignette](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/tidyllm/vignettes/getting-started.html).

### Climate Analysis

[carbonr](https://cran.r-project.org/package=carbonr) v0.2.1: Provides a tool for calculating carbon-equivalent emissions based in the UK Government's [Greenhouse Gas Conversion Factors](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/greenhouse-gas-reporting-conversion-factors-2023) report, it facilitates transparent emissions calculations for various sectors, including travel, accommodation, and clinical activities. See the [vignette](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/carbonr/vignettes/introduction-to-carbonr.html).


[fluxfinder](https://cran.r-project.org/package=fluxfinder) v1.0.0: Parse static-chamber greenhouse gas measurement files generated by a variety of instruments; compute flux rates using multi-observation metadata; and generate diagnostic metrics and plots. Designed to be easy to integrate into reproducible scientific workflows. There is an [Introduction](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/fluxfinder/vignettes/intro-to-fluxfinder.html) and a [vignette](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/fluxfinder/vignettes/intro-to-fluxfinder.html) on integrating with the `gasfluxes` package.

![](fluxfinder.png){fig-alt="Time series colored by metadata"}

### Computational Methods

[gmresls](https://cran.r-project.org/package=gmresls) v0.2.2: Implements a method to solve a least squares system Ax~=b (dim(A)=(m,n) with m >= n) with a precondition matrix B: BAx=Bb (dim(B)=(n,m)) based on the General Minimal Residual Algorithm of [Saad & Schultz (1986)](https://epubs.siam.org/doi/10.1137/0907058). See [README](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/gmresls/readme/README.html).

[mappeR](https://cran.r-project.org/package=mappeR) v1.3.0: Implements an algorithm that generalizes the concept of a [Reeb Graph](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reeb_graph) as described in [MÃ©moli and Carlsson (2007)](https://research.math.osu.edu/tgda/mapperPBG.pdf) for a Topological Data Analysis of high dimensional data. Look [here](https://github.com/Uiowa-Applied-Topology/mappeR) for examples.

![](mapper.png){fig-alt="Example of mappeR Graph"}


[TensorTools](https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=TensorTools) v1.0.0: Provides a set of tools for basic tensor operators based on the Discrete Fourier Transform including the eigenvalue,  QR decomposition, LU decompositions of a tensor, and the calculation of the inverse of a tensor and the transpose of a symmetric tensor. See [Kernfeld et al. (2015)](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0024379515004358?via%3Dihub) for the details and the [vignette](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/TensorTools/vignettes/TensorTools.html) for examples. Note, in this context, a tensor is a multidimensional array



### Data

[openFDA](https://cran.r-project.org/package=openFDA) v0.1.0: Facilitates access to U.S. Food and Drug Administrations [openFDA](https://open.fda.gov/
) data on drugs, devices, foodstuffs, tobacco, and more. See [Kass-Hout et al. (2016)](https://academic.oup.com/jamia/article/23/3/596/2908999?login=false) for background and the [vignette](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/openFDA/vignettes/openFDA.html) to get started.

[ozbabynames](https://cran.r-project.org/package=ozbabynames) v0.1.0: Provides data on the most popular baby names by sex and year for each state in Australia as provided by the state and territory governments. The quality and quantity of the data varies with the state. Look [here](https://pkg.robjhyndman.com/ozbabynames/) for information.o

![](ozbaby.gif){fig-alt="Gif of bubs dubbed"}

### Epidemiology

[epichains](https://cran.r-project.org/package=epichains) v0.1.1: Provides methods to simulate and analyse the size and length of branching processes with an arbitrary offspring distribution. These can be used, for example, to analyse the distribution of chain sizes or length of infectious disease outbreaks, as discussed in [Farrington et al. (2003)](https://academic.oup.com/biostatistics/article-abstract/4/2/279/245106?redirectedFrom=fulltext&login=false). There are six vignettes including a [Getting Started](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/epichains/vignettes/epichains.html) guide and [Theoretical Background](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/epichains/vignettes/theoretical_background.html) 

![](epichains.png){fig-alt="Diagram depicting chain"}

[epizootic](https://cran.r-project.org/package=epizootic) v1.0.0: Extends the pattern-oriented modeling framework of the `poems` package to provide functions for modeling disease transmission on a population scale in a spatiotemporally explicit manner and includes seasonal time steps, dispersal functions, objects that store disease states, and a population simulator that includes disease dynamics. See the [vignettte](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/epizootic/vignettes/mycoplasma.html) for an extended example.

![](epizootic.png){fig-alt="Map of susceptible population"}


[serosv](https://cran.r-project.org/package=serosv) v1.0.1: Implements tools to estimate infectious diseases parameters using serological data. Implemented models include SIR models, nonparametric models, semiparametric models, and hierarchical models which are based on the book by [Hens et al. (2013)](https://link.springer.com/book/10.1007/978-1-4614-4072-7). There are eight vignettes including [Hierarchical Bayesian Models]() and [Modeling directly from antibody levels](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/serosv/vignettes/model_quantitative_data.html).

![](serosv.png){fig-alt="Model visualization showing sero prevalence and fprce of infection"}

### Genomics

[GSEMA](https://cran.r-project.org/package=GSEMA) v0.99.3: Provides functions to perform various steps of gene set enrichment meta-analysis including meta-analysis of effect sizes from different pathways in different studies. See the [vignette](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/GSEMA/vignettes/GSEMA.html) for examples.

![](GSEMA.png){fig-alt="Heatmap of random effects model"}

[phylotypr](https://cran.r-project.org/package=phylotypr) v0.1.0: Implements Naive Bayesian Classifier from the Ribosomal Database Project that traditionally has been used to classify 16S rRNA gene sequences to bacterial taxonomic outlines, but which applies to any type of gene sequence. See [Wang et al. (2007)](https://journals.asm.org/doi/10.1128/aem.00062-07) for background and the [vignette](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/phylotypr/vignettes/phylotypr.html) for examples.


### Machine Learning

[textpress](https://cran.r-project.org/package=textpress) v1.0.0: Provides a Natural Language Processing (NLP) toolkit focused on search-centric workflows with minimal dependencies. The package offers key features for web scraping, text processing, corpus search, and text embedding generation via the [HuggingFace API](https://huggingface.co/docs/api-inference/index). See [README](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/textpress/readme/README.html) for examples.


### Medicine

[eyetools](https://cran.r-project.org/package=eyetools) v0.7.2: Provides functions to help researchers analyze eye-data enabling the automation of actions across a pipeline that includes transforming binocular data and gap repair and event-based processing such as fixations, saccades, and entry and duration in areas of interest. Functions implement the fixation and saccade detection methods proposed by [Salvucci and Goldberg (2000)](https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/355017.355028) and visualize eye movement. See the [Intrudction](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/eyetools/vignettes/eyetools.html).

![](eyetools.png){fig-alt="Eye movement plots"}


[MedDataSets](https://cran.r-project.org/package=MedDataSets) v0.1.0: Provides an extensive collection of datasets related to medicine, diseases, treatments, drugs, and public health covering topics such as drug effectiveness, vaccine trials, survival rates, infectious disease outbreaks, and medical treatments. including AIDS, cancer, bacterial infections, and COVID-19, and information on pharmaceuticals and vaccines. These datasets are sourced from the R ecosystem and other R packages. See the [vignette](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/MedDataSets/vignettes/intro_meddatasets.html).

[ODT](https://cran.r-project.org/package=ODT) v1.0.0: Implements a tree-based method specifically designed for personalized medicine applications that uses genomic and mutational data to identify optimal drug recommendations tailored to individual patient profiles. See [Gimeno et al. (2023)](https://academic.oup.com/bib/article/24/4/bbad200/7186396?login=false) for the details and the [vignette](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/ODT/vignettes/ODT.html) for an example.

![](ODT.png){fig-alt="Decision Tree"}

[trtswitch](https://cran.r-project.org/package=trtswitch) v0.1.1: Implements rank-preserving structural failure time model (RPSFTM), iterative parameter estimation (IPE), inverse probability of censoring weights (IPCW), and two-stage estimation (TSE) methods for treatment switching in randomized clinical trials. See [Latimer et al. (2017)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25416688/) for background. There are five vignettes including descriptions of [RPSFTM](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/trtswitch/vignettes/rpsftm.html) and [IPE](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/trtswitch/vignettes/ipe.html).

[UnplanSimon](https://cran.r-project.org/package=UnplanSimon) v0.1.0: Implements methods to manage under- and over-enrollment in Simon's Two-Stage Design by providing adaptive threshold adjustments and sample size recalibration, and  post-inference analysis tools to support clinical trial design and evaluation. See the [vignette](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/UnplanSimon/vignettes/UnplanSimon.html).


### Quality Management

[r6qualitytools](https://cran.r-project.org/package=r6qualitytools) v1.0.1: Implements a suite of statistical tools for Quality Management, designed around the Define, Measure, Analyze, Improve, and Control (DMAIC) cycle used in Six Sigma methodology. It refactors the `qualitytools`package incorporating 'R6' object-oriented programming for increased flexibility and performance and replaces traditional graphics with modern, interactive visualizations. Look [here](https://github.com/Fabianenc/r6qualitytool) for examples.

![](r6quality.png){fig-alt="Process controol charts"}







### Statistics

[clusTMB](https://cran.r-project.org/package=clustTMB): v0.1.0: Fits a spatio-temporal finite mixture model using the `TMB` package.. Covariate, spatial and temporal random effects can be incorporated into the gating formula using multinomial logistic regression, the expert formula using a generalized linear mixed model framework, or both. See the vignettes [Covariance Structure](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/clustTMB/vignettes/CovarianceStructure.html) and [Meuse Example](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/clustTMB/vignettes/SpatialExMeuseData.html).

![](clustTMB.png){fig-alt="Correlation plots of concentration levels"}

### Statistics (Continued)

[extrememix](https://cran.r-project.org/package=extrememix) v0.0.1: Fits extreme value mixture models, which are models for tails not requiring selection of a threshold, for continuous data. See [Behrens et al.(2004)](https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1191/1471082X04st075oa) and [Nascimento et al. (2011)](https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11222-011-9270-z) for the theory and the [vignette](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/extrememix/vignettes/my-vignette.html) for examples.

![](extrememix.png){fig-alt="Plot of Predictive Distribution"}






[MECfda](https://cran.r-project.org/package=MECfda) v0.1.0: Implements functions to solve scalar-on-function linear models, including generalized linear mixed effect model and quantile linear regression model, and bias correction estimation methods due to measurement error. Details about the measurement error bias correction methods. See [Luan et al. (2023)](https://arxiv.org/abs/2305.12624), [Tekwe et al. (2022)](https://academic.oup.com/biostatistics/article/23/4/1218/6596004?login=false), [Zhang et al. (2023)](https://www3.stat.sinica.edu.tw/statistica/J33N3/J33N321/J33N321.html), and [Tekwe et al. (2019)](https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/sim.8179) for background and the [vignette](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/MECfda/vignettes/MECfda.html) for an introduction.

[multipois](https://cran.r-project.org/package=multpois) v0.2.0: Implements a method to analyze polytomous responses with three or more unordered categories by transforming nominal response data into counts for each categorical alternative. These counts are then analyzed using (mixed) Poisson regression as per [Baker (1994)](https://www.jstor.org/stable/2348134?origin=crossref). 

![](multipois.png){fig-alt="Mosaic plot of Y by, X1, X2"}



[spStack](https://cran.r-project.org/package=spStack) v1.0.1: Fits Bayesian hierarchical spatial process models for point-referenced Gaussian, Poisson, binomial, and binary data using stacking of predictive densities by sampling from analytically available posterior distributions conditional upon some candidate values of the spatial process parameters. See [Zhang et al. (2024)](https://arxiv.org/abs/2304.12414) and [Pan et al. (2024)](https://arxiv.org/abs/2406.04655) for background and the [vignette](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/spStack/vignettes/spStack.html) for examples.

![](spStack.png){fig-alt="Spatial Surface Plots"}

[svyROC](https://cran.r-project.org/package=svyROC) v1.0.0: Provides functions to estimate the receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve, area under the curve (AUC) and optimal cut-off points for individual classification taking into account complex sampling designs when working with complex survey data. See [Iparragirre et al. (2024)](https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/sta4.635), [Iparragirre et al. (2022)](https://www.idescat.cat/sort/sort461/46.1.6.Iparragirre-etal.pdf) and [Iparragirre & Barrio (2024)](https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-031-65723-8_7) for the theory and [README](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/svyROC/readme/README.html) for an example. 

![](svyROC.png){fig-alt="ROC Curve"}

[VDPO](https://cran.r-project.org/package=VDPO) v0.1.0: Provides a comprehensive set of tools for analyzing and manipulating functional data with non-uniform lengths, and addresses two common scenarios in functional data analysis: Variable Domain Data, and Partially Observed Data.  See [Amaro et al. (2024)](https://arxiv.org/abs/2401.05839) for the details. There are two vignettes: [Introduction](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/VDPO/vignettes/VDPO-01-introduction.html) and [Model fitting for variable domain data](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/VDPO/vignettes/VDPO-02-vd-models.html).

![](VDPO.png){fig-alt="Heatmap of model Beta"}





### Time Series

[FTSgof](https://cran.r-project.org/package=FTSgof) v1.0.0: Offers tools for the analysis of functional time series data, focusing on white noise hypothesis testing and goodness-of-fit evaluations, alongside functions for simulating data and advanced visualization techniques. See [Kokoszka et al. (2017)](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0047259X17303512?via%3Dihub), [Yeh et al. (2023)](https://projecteuclid.org/journals/electronic-journal-of-statistics/volume-17/issue-1/Functional-spherical-autocorrelation--A-robust-estimate-of-the-autocorrelation/10.1214/23-EJS2112.full), [Kim et al. (2023)](https://projecteuclid.org/journals/statistics-surveys/volume-17/issue-none/White-noise-testing-for-functional-time-series/10.1214/23-SS143.full), and [Rice et al. (2020)](https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/jtsa.12532) for the theory and the [vignette](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/FTSgof/vignettes/FTSgof.html) for examples.

![](FTSgof.png){fig-alt="#d Time Series Plot"}

[utsf](https://cran.r-project.org/package=utsf) v1.0.0: Implements a uniform interface for univariate time series forecasting using different regression models in an autoregressive way, and provides features such as preprocessing and estimation of forecast accuracy. See the [vignette](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/utsf/vignettes/utsf.html).

![](utsf.png){fig-alt="Time Series with KNN Forecast"}




### Utilities

[ctypesio](https://cran.r-project.org/package=ctypesio) v0.1.1: Provides functions for reading and writing binary data (with files, connections, and raw vectors) using `C` type descriptions that convert data between `C` types and R types while checking for values outside the type limits, `NA` values, etc. See the vignettes [Parsing JPEG Markers](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/ctypesio/vignettes/parse-jpeg.html) and [Handcrafting a WAV file](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/ctypesio/vignettes/wave-format.html).


[GitStats](https://cran.r-project.org/package=GitStats) v2.1.2: Provides functions to obtain standardized data from multiple *Git* services, including GitHub and GitLab. There are vignettes on [Getting Repositories](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/GitStats/vignettes/get_repos_with_code.html) and [Setting Hosts](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/GitStats/vignettes/set_hosts.html). 

[mall](https://cran.r-project.org/package=mall) v0.1.0: Enables users to run multiple Large Language Model predictions against a table. The predictions run row-wise over a specified column. It works using a one-shot prompt, along with the current row's content. Look [here](https://mlverse.github.io/mall/) got examples.

[MDPIexploreR](https://cran.r-project.org/package=MDPIexploreR) v0.2.0: Provides tools to scrape and analyze data from the [MDPI journals](https://www.mdpi.com/about/journals) including function to extract metrics such as submission-to-acceptance times, article types, plot data and explore patterns of self-citations. See the [vignette](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/MDPIexploreR/vignettes/introduction_MDPIexploreR.html)

![](MDPI.png){fig-alt="List of first six MDPI Journals"}



### Visualization

[affiner](https://cran.r-project.org/package=affiner) v0.1.1: Provides functions to dilate, permute, project, reflect, rotate, shear, and translate 2D and 3D points. Supports parallel projections including oblique projections such as the cabinet projection as well as axonometric projections such as the isometric projection. There is an [Introduction](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/affiner/vignettes/affiner.html) and a [vignette]() on geometry.

![](affiner.png){height=50%, width=50%}

[doceplot](https://cran.r-project.org/package=diceplot) v0.1.3: Provides functions to visualize data with more than two categorical variables and additional continuous variables that is particularly useful for exploring complex categorical data in the context of pathway analysis across multiple conditions. Look [here](https://dice-and-domino-plot.readthedocs.io/en/latest/) for documentation.

![](diceplot.png){fig-alt="Plot with 6 categorical variables"}

[ggcompare](https://cran.r-project.org/package=ggcompare) v0.0.2: Add mean comparison annotations to a `ggplot` to indicate if two or more groups are significantly different. For comparisons between two groups, the p-value is calculated by t-test (parametric) or Wilcoxon rank sum test (nonparametric). For comparisons among more than two groups, the p-value is calculated by One-way ANOVA (parametric) or Kruskal-Wallis test (nonparametric). Look [here](https://github.com/HMU-WH/ggcompare/) for examples.

![](ggcompare.png){fig-alt="Boxplots annotated with pvalues"}

[ggpca](https://cran.r-project.org/package=ggpca) v0.1.2: Provides tools for creating publication-ready dimensionality reduction plots, including Principal Component Analysis (PCA), t-Distributed Stochastic Neighbor Embedding (t-SNE), and Uniform Manifold Approximation and Projection (UMAP) using the `ggplot2` framework. See the [vignette](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/ggpca/vignettes/ggpca-examples.htm).

![](ggpca.png){fig-alt="PCA plot"}


[plotscaper](https://cran.r-project.org/package=plotscaper) v0.2.3: Implements a framework for creating interactive figures for data exploration. All plots are automatically linked and support several kinds of interactive features, including selection, zooming, panning, and parameter manipulation. There is an [Introduction](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/plotscaper/vignettes/plotscaper.html) and four additional vignettes including [Available Interactions](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/plotscaper/vignettes/available-interactions.html) and [Layout](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/plotscaper/vignettes/layout.html).

![](plotscaper.png){fig-alt="Four interlinked plots"}

[vchartr](https://cran.r-project.org/package=vchartr) v0.1.3: Provides an `htmlwidgets` interface to [VChart](https://www.visactor.io/vchart), a cross-platform charting library and expressive data storyteller. See the [vignette](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/vchartr/vignettes/vchartr.html).

![](vchart.png){fig-alt="Examples of charts"}

:::
